I can't bear the thoughts of dividing, not I— Division, why, I never could learn it at school— one hun∣dred thousand pounds, divided into nine parts— let me see— nine times nine is, a, a, eighty-nine; that's wrong; nine times eleven is an hundred and six and four over; that's too much; but I'm no scholar; well never mind, no matter; charity begins at home, and he must be must be the greatest fool on earth that cheats himself: I think I'm old enough to have more wit—He that cheats another can wipe off the sin by restoring four-fold; but he that cheats himself, the sin will lie at his own door, and it will be out of his power to make himself restitution— I'll go and inform the collector; then I shall have one half to myself, the other will go to the king —They'll call me traytor, but I don't care, let them laugh that wins—It's an old saying,
and a true one—that is—let me see—aye, I have it, One bird in hand is better far, Than two that's in the push—no, no, Than two that in the bushes are. Aye, that's it; I remember it's so on my neighbour Sy∣monds's sign; but here's fifty thousand birds in the cage, and all prety yellow-birds every one of them— Oh! they'll make delightful musick, and make me sing too—I'll e'en go to the collector; I must'n't lose any time, no, no; (He looks up) I think this is the house; aye He knocks at the door, the collecter appears.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: What is your business sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Why, why, sir, I have an information to make you, concerning a chest of treasure, that was dug out of the ground last night—Mr. Hum, sir, and se∣veral others are concern'd; and it grieves my conscience to cheat the king of his lawful right; so, pray sir, seize it instantly, for me and his majesty. I expect all con∣cern'd will be at my house immediately to open and share it—Put the broad R on it and then we shall be safe —you must act for me and the king, and we'll reward you handsomely.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Poh, poh, 'tis not possible; it's only some scheme to make you ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Indeed sir, it's a real truth; for this piece of money (Shewing the piece) drop'd out of the chest, when we took it out of the ground—Look here sir, see it— Pray be expeditious, do sir be expeditious.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Well sir, if you insist upon it, I must seize it

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: My loyalty to the king, obliges me to insist upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I'll wait on you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V. A Room in Washball's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Scene opens and discovers M' Snip, Trushoop and Rac∣coon, sitting on the Chest, and old Gabriel, Wash∣ball's Servant, standing by.
Enter Hum, Parchment, Quadrant and Rattletrap.

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: Gabriel, where's your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: He's just stepd out sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Will he be in soon?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab
SP.P: Aye. I believe he will.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad
SP.P: Oh! here he comes! but who the devil's that with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: The collector! Egad, this is what I did not expect—It will not do to dupe him; we must let him into the secret. Aside to Hum.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Leave that to me, [Enter Collector and Washball. Hum takes the Collector aside and says] Sir I'm sorry we have been the means of giving you this trouble; it's a scheme of diversion only; please not to notice it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: Just as I thought—Mr. Hum your servant; gentlemen yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Sir, sir, I beg you'd stay— Pray do your duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Mr. Washball, It's an affair too intricate for me. I must first advise with the kings attorney. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh you cursed ould traytor! ar'nt you asham'd of yoursalf to be chateing us after this way?

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: I never heard o such a villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab
SP.P: Heres queer doings here. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: M' Sn.
SP.P: Ye eenfamous auld scoondril; ye turn'd een∣former, to get the ane half to yoursel—but ye're oot mon. I'se a mind to leeghten your heed by ane of your luggs.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab
SP.P: Worse and worse. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac
SP.P: What did you tink we were all fools, to be cheated by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum
SP.P: Nothing can equal this! open the chest gen∣tlemen, who knows but the king's attorney will be upon our backs directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: A traytor, gentlemen, of all mankind is the most despicable wretch. You see, gentlemen that old curmudgeon thinks nothing of betraying his soul, for the sake of his body not the least regard to his solemn oath

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: How he abuses my master. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: Mr. Trushoop, where's your adz? open the chest.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus
SP.P: Augh fait! and here we are bote, at your shar∣viss my dare.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Strives to prevent them, Hum, Rattletrap, Parchment and Quaarant hold him, he struggles to get from them and bawls) Where's the Collector? Mr. Collector —touh it at your peril, you villains! I'll swear rob∣bery against you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab
SP.P: I believe they're going to rob my master Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: Go on with your business gentlemen, open the chest. Trushoop, Raccoon and M' Snip opening the chest.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash
SP.P: Touch it at your peril I say—it belongs to me and the king.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus
SP.P: Belong to de devil you teif— we'll soon see who'll feel the sharing of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab
SP.P: I never see the like before. Lifting up his hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Murder! murder! fire thieves! ravishment! hell and fury!—Betty, Betty, bring down the bags you made—Run Gabriel, and call the Collector.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Yes, I will, and I'll go for the constable; sorrow on me but I believe they'll murder my master. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Dere the chest opens.

SP.SPEAKER: M' Sn
SP.P: It's aupen
SP.STAGE: They let Washball go, he runs towards the chest; the aupes all scramble to get their shares, and in the scuffle push down Washball and overset the chest, out tumble the contents

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Rising.) Give me my share! give me my share! give me my share!
SP.STAGE: M' Snip, Trushoop Raccoon and Washball look at one another confus'd.

SP.SPEAKER: M' Sn.
SP.P: Hoot mon what the de'els aw this? nathing but staines—I kn weel enough wha it is— de'el dom me sirs, but I'll ha' jontlemen's saytisfakeshon.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus
SP.P: Fait, and we're all humbugg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac
SP.P: De devil dis is a scheme of broder Hum's— I'll second your resolution Mr. M' Snip—do you gib de chalenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: By my showl! and I've been made a fool of for the future; but I'll take care for the time past.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I didn't tink broder Hum wou'd serve me so; but egad! I'll inform de lodge of dis— Dere's Rattle∣trap too wid his stars and tings, plague on dem all; and has Mrs. Placket made de fool of me too wid her conjuring—It can't be, for I tink she lobes me, or she wou'dn't call me her Cooney, and her cock-a-dandy— Dad I'll get a bottle of her water, and carry it to doctor Witt's, den I'll know if she's a conjurer or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh I taught I shou'd be cannonicled for a shaint; but it's all over—Arra curse these generati∣ons of snakes— I mane wipers.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh! I'm abus'd— I shall die, O dear! I shall die (Lifting up his hands.) Poor Washball, disappointed Washball (Hum, Quadrant, Parchment and Rattletrap alternately calling canoe; Washball chasing them about the stage, and endeavouring to strike them with his cane.) Get out of my house, you villains! (They halloo canoe.) you cursed villains! (Canoe again.) you dogs! (Canoe.) you hell hounds! (Canoe.) you devils▪ (Canoe) curse you all! (Canoe) They laugh and run off the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Arra this is the devil's own works, and they're all the devil's own children; by my showl! and they'll do grate pannance for this. Sings.

LG.HEAD: AIR XVI. The Milking Pail. (To be sung slow, and with an Irish accent)
I.
LG.L: Arra what a fool was I; by my showl! I think I'll cry,
When I spake of all thish, it encraases my blish;
'Twill kill me afore I die.
Fait I'll now show m faash, t'escape all disgraash,
For me theyll make a true jast.
No more will my foes,
Drive me by my nose,
In bogs o'er my toes,
Spoiling brogues and shoes,
And carry the ampty chast.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Augh! feel my back is quite soar, fait becaze it made me roar.
How it broke all my bones, by pulling bricks and stones,
To the mill from Washball's dore.
To hear the pain and smart, I fale just in my haart,
My fut is both sick and lame.
With canew and bote,
Ive muddy'd my cote;
My wife'll cut my trote,
The de'el take the tote;
Augh me! they'll make a great game.

SP.SPEAKER: M' Sn.
SP.P: De'el dom 'em aw.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac
SP.P: Dis, dis is my own faut for being too credu∣lous: I put too much confidence in dose I tought my friends, and dey deceib'd me. Had I been satisfy'd wid my station, and follow'd a birtuous course of life, den I might have been happy to dis day, and had noting to trouble my peace of mind.—But now I hab seen my folly and former bickedness, I bill take de resolution to lead a new life, and follow my bus'ness wid honesty and industry, and hab noting more to say to de banities, bexations and alewments of dis world; and from hence∣foat my study shall be birtue, which paat I will pursue to the end of my day.

SP.SPEAKER: M' Sn.
SP.P: Confusion to the vullains; I must e'en gang and fut up my shap-boord agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P:
O dear, I'm robbd of my money, my health and my ease—nothing's left for me now but to grieve and lament—How shall I procure my peace again▪— Let me see—attend my business—what then—if a cus∣tomer should laugh under the operation of my razor, egad, I shou'd think he aim'd at me, for being this silly old fool, and ten to one but I might cut his throat for madness—Dress a wig—ha— I shall think my blocks grin at me—I'll instantly go and burn them all— If I hear the noise of children in the street, I shall think they bawl ca∣noe, canoe—Confound this word—I'd give five hundred pound it was was made high treason to utter it; then I wou'd hang every one of those cursed rogues— O dear! what can I do?—If I rail against them publickly, I shall only have the cold comfort of, "'Tis a piece of diversion, nothing else"—Hellish diversion—Suppose I
shou'd try to laugh it off—Alas! alas! I can't do it— I shan't be in a laughing humour these seven years I'm afraid.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Meanwell and Lucy. (They kneel down.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: Sir we crave your blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Go to the devil you dog

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh Lucy! sure you're not marry'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: It is so Mr. Trushoop— Pray endeavour to pa∣cify my uncle— pray gentlemen interpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh the gipsey! I shall run stark staring mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Come, come, Mr. Washball, how can you be so angry wid her she's a pretty young cretur.

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: Pray sir pardon us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Pray uncle give us your blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Let me intate you sir, to blass 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: I charge you both, tell me the truth, are you really married?

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: 'Tis really so sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Dear uncle it's true.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash
SP.P: O dear! O lack-a-day! Well, if the knot is ty'd, there's no untying it now.

SP.SPEAKER: M' Sn
SP.P: Come, come mon gie 'em your blessing; troth shes a smirky bonny lass.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Well, since it is so, God bless you both — rise—but remember children, that bare walls makes giddy housewives.

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: Sir, we thank you for your kind condescen∣tion, and I must now inform you that I have this day received a letter from Jamaica, giving an account of my uncle's death, inclosing a copy of his will; by which I understand he hath left me five thousand pounds in cash, with all his real and personal estate; a part of which cash is remitted me, in the Brig Welcome, Capt. Trusty.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: I am glad to hear it—it revives my drooping spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P:
Notwithstanding this flush of fortune, I bear the same respect to your neice as heretofore; and you
may depend sir, I shall always make it my study to me∣rit your esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: You have my blessing, and may you live com∣fortably together, and see many happy days, and be blest with a train of dutiful children, to comfort you in your old age—and, O! that I, who have one foot in the grave, and the other scarcely out, had been con∣tented, then I should have been happy in my old age, and not have involved myself in this labyrinth of trou∣ble and confusion—But let it be a warning to others, not to listen to idle schemes, and give way to vain ima∣ginations; which had nearly prov'd fatal to me—for he whose desires are unbounded, and is weak enough to listen to artful designing men, stands upon a dangerous precipice whose foundation must sink and he innevitably perish. Sings.

LG.HEAD: AIR XVII. Ah! who is me, poor Walley cry'd.
LG.L: (To be sung slow.) Ah! who is me, poor wretched I,
With broken heart and down cast eyes;
To ease my mind where shall I fly?
A prey to knaves, poor Washball dies.
Let future generations take,
Example by my dismal fall,
Nor gods of gold, or idols make,
So shun the fate of poor Washball.

SP.P: And now my friends, Mr. Trushoop, Mr. M' Snip and Mr. Raccoon, I expect you will honor us with your company at dinner—We'll strive to make ourselves as merry as we can, and forget our folly.—Gabriel, call in the neighbours, bring your fiddle and play for us, and we'll have a dance,.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: (without.) I will sir, sorrow on me but I will, for we havn't had a dance since last christmass.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: In the mean while, my children, give us a song.

LG.HEAD: AIR XVIII. Jolly Bacchanalian.
LG.L: Meanwell sings. Banish sorrow welcome joy,
Let's strike up the sprightly dance;
Mirth abound without alloy;
Tune your lutes, your pipes advance;
Sound your notes in lofty strains,
Joyn ye nymphs and jovial swains,
Banish care and be at rest,
Of a bad bargain make the best. Banish care, &c. Lucy sings.
Room for joy, how blest am I,
In a husband and a friend,
Virtuous love shall never die,
Tho' our lives will surely end.
Virgins all example take;
Virtue love, for virtue's sake,
Constant be as turtle dove,
Let your theme be virtuous love. Constant be, &c.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Gabriel with his fiddle, and Neighbours: they strike up a Country Dance, calld EXCUSE ME.

LG.L: After the Dance Washball says, In search of treasure, we are led astray,
Believing fully, what deceivers say.
They tread unsure, who 'gainst there senses run,
False steps pursue and rush to be undone,
Curs'd by themselves, laugh'd at by ev'ry one. Exeunt.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Down derry derry down▪ down down derry.

SP.SPEAKER: Rattle.
SP.P: Master Hum▪ methinks your won'drous merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum
SP.P: Gad, so I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Rattle.
SP.L: That I can plainly see,

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Sing tantararara, rara, raree.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.L: Of all the plays I ever saw or heard—

SP.SPEAKER: Rattle.
SP.P: This beats them all, I swear now by my beard.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: 'Tis false you con'ring rogue, 'tis sorry stuff.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.L: Your servant ma'am for you make noise enough
SP.STAGE: Hum, Quadrant and Rattletrap leave her, bowing.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.L: Zounds! what's this? the devil and all to pay;
Broadside and broadside, damn'd warm work to day,
I'll drop a stern and let them end the fray.

SP.SPEAKER: Plac.
SP.L: 'Tis nonsense all, methinks I hear some say,
But hang 'em how they laugh'd and clat away:
There's one hoarse voice he croak'd, 'tis very witty,
A female next squeak'd out, 'tis vastly pretty;
Lord! says a third, how it alarms the city.
Plague on them all, Oh! how I shall be teaz'd.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Meanwell and Lucy, lock'd arm in arm and cross the Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Encircled in thy arms▪ Oh! how I'm pleas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.L: Confound the play, it's made a wond'rous racket

SP.SPEAKER: Plac.
SP.L: Oh split 'em all, thro' breeches, coat and jacket

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Come, don't cry pet, don't cry my pretty Placket.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh monstrous! laugh, and not one word of sence.

SP.SPEAKER: M' Sn
SP.P: But you see mon, it pleas'd the audience.

SP.SPEAKER: Plac
SP.L: Aye to be sure—but 'twas at our expence Crys.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: What fools theyv'e made of us—Oh dear! Oh dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: That's true for you! but by my showl 'twas queer.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.L: Oh shame! Oh shame! my rage is to excess

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: [without.] The boxes laugh'd aloud— you heard I guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: 'Twill drive me crazy— It's a mortal blow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rattle.
SP.P: [without▪] Ne'er fear old cock— A digging we'll all go. Sings.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Ridiculous scenes they were transacting.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: [without.] Aye, but how I laugh'd while it was acting.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: A play indeed!—a play should have some wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: (without.) Pray who made you a judge? what said the pit?

SP.SPEAKER: Rattle.
SP.P: They laugh'd aloud and took a deal of notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: One girl I thought▪ Ha▪ ha, she'd split her bodice.

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.L: The boxes clap'd — the ladies cry'd bless me

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: So pleas'd they were, they laugh'd out, He, he, he.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: That dog Hum's a very wicked body.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Tol de rol, lol de rol, tol de rol loddy. Sings.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.L: Come, come away, for this will never do.
Good Night t'ye all.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Canoe.

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: Canoe.

SP.SPEAKER: Rattle.
SP.P: Canoe.
